newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper ends mostly up on short-covering.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper ends mostly up on short-covering.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended mostly up on Tuesday on technical short-covering after sharp falls on Monday, traders said.
The most active January 1997 contract ended at 19,920 yuan ($2,399) per tonne, rising 80 yuan. It opened at an intra-day low of 19,850 and hit a high of 19,950.
October ended unchanged at 20,450 yuan, November rose 40 to 20,150, December 80 to 19,960, February 60 to 19,900, March 60 to 19,960 and April fell 40 to 19,910.
Combined volume fell to 21,430 tonnes from 71,250.
Copper opened little changed after an overnight flat performance on the London Metal Exchange, and short-covering pushed the contracts to close near their intra-day highs.
Traders said a lack of follow-up market-moving news triggered technical short-covering from retail investors.
"Shanghai investors believe that the short-term downward potential is limited despite current losses on the London Metal Exchange," one trader said.
"But all later-maturing contracts met strong resistance at the 20,000-yuan level, which indicated the mid- and long-term trend is for a further drop," he added.
"Decreasing volume showed that only some speculators liquidated their short positions, with most investors waiting for market-moving news," a second trader said.
Analysts said that the general outlook of copper was for further declines following the breakthrough of the key 20,000 yuan support level and on poor fundamentals.
Aluminium ended down. October fell 70 to 13,880 yuan per tonne, November 150 to 13,800 and December 50 to 13,850.
Combined volume fell to 430 tonnes from 1,400.
